Paulo Coelho is mainly regarded as one of Brazil's greatest writers. He was born in 1947 in Rio de Janeiro, and his works have sold more than 300 million copies worldwide. The Brazilian novelist has served as an inspiration to young authors in Brazil and throughout the world.

By accompanying narrators on journeys that drastically transform the character and the reader's world vision, his works lure the reader into the depths of spiritual experiences. Paulo's intriguing characters in practically every novel constantly challenge readers to learn something new about themselves. We've listed Paulo Coelho's top novels below if you want to read some fantastic language while pondering your feelings and ideas about yourself and the world.

The Alchemist

The Alchemist, published in 1988, is often recognised as Paulo Coelho's finest work, and it is the publication that catapulted him to literary fame. The plot revolves around Santiago, a young shepherd from Spain who journeys across the arid Andalusian area. Santiago is forced to seek refuge with his herd in an abandoned ancient church along the way, and one of his thoughts reminds him that he is destined to uncover Egypt's pyramids and all the wealth they conceal.

The dream haunts Santiago, and after meeting a wise alchemist, he accepts his fate and departs from the Andalusian farms to fulfil his destiny in Africa. Along the voyage, Santiago and the alchemist meet various strange personalities, and the young shepherd discovers a better understanding of himself.

The book was a significant success, propelling Paulo into the world literary arena after being translated into 35 languages and selling millions of copies. The Alchemist is a must-read for everyone interested in Paulo's work.

The Devil and Miss Pyrm

The Devil and Miss Prym, published in 2000, is a novella that urges readers to think about greed, cowardice, and fear. The plot revolves around an odd stranger who comes to the secluded French village of Viscos with a suitcase loaded with 11 gold bars and one essential question: 'Are people good or evil?'

Chantal Prym, a local barmaid, becomes pivotal to the plot when she seduces the stranger in the hope that he will be able to provide her with a more exciting existence than the one she had grown weary of in Hamlet. The stranger gives Chantal and the villagers a choice: they may share his wealth if they agree to murder someone. In this book, Coelho examined the underlying character of mankind and its inclination to perpetrate atrocities for the sake of greed through the lens of this evil proposition.

Manuscript Found in Accra

The Manuscript found in Accra was published in 2013. The story is set in 11th-century Jerusalem. It depicts the narrative of the inhabitants who lived beyond the old city's walls as crusaders approached, bringing with them the eventual slaughter of the local populace. Like the previous two Paulo Coelho novels, he draws directly on the anxieties and concerns of the city's residents, allowing the reader to reflect on their own emotions. A mysterious individual known as 'Copt' plays a significant part in the plot, delivering talks to fearful people that push them to confront their feelings.

Despite the fact that the crusader army is almost within hearing distance, Copt instructs the scared people to evaluate all elements of their existence rather than allowing terror to drown out everything else that is vital.

The Witch of Portobello

The Witch of Portobello, published in 2006, chronicles the story of another mystery individual, Athena, a young Transylvanian woman. Many other characters, some of whom had never met Athena, narrate her narrative, encouraging the reader to ponder essential values such as love, passion, and sacrifice. The book begins with Athena's death and then proceeds backwards to her birth. As the tale is told from multiple viewpoints, it becomes evident that Athena's life is filled with instability and tragedy. Her mother abandoned her as a child because her father was a foreigner. A wealthy Lebanese couple eventually adopts this orphaned girl, and she ends up studying in London, attempting to compensate for the shortcomings of her childhood, only for it all to end tragically.

The Pilgrimage

The Pilgrimage, published in 1987, was one of Coelho's first works. The novel is based on Paulo's personal experience travelling the Camino de Santiago pilgrimage in Spain during his hippy years. Paulo's trek carried him throughout Spain, concluding at the northern city of Santiago de Compostela.

The plot revolves around self-discovery. Like many others who embarked on a long journey with only a map and a bag, Paulo spent a lot of time contemplating himself and the world as he journeyed alone and engaged with pilgrims from all walks of life.

As usual, the novel has a mysterious figure. This time, Petrus encourages Paulo to think for himself and question society's standards that frequently keep people away from following their true desires in life. If you're seeking inspiration for personal progress, this is one of Paulo Coelho's best book suggestions.

Veronika Decides to Die

'Veronika Decides to Die' is a lovely story about hope and happiness. The plot centres around Veronika, a young Slovenian woman with everything a woman in her prime might desire. She has a wonderful career, many boyfriends, and a loving family. She is, however, dissatisfied with her existence and commits suicide. She takes sleeping medications and waits for her death, which never comes. She awakens in a hospital, informed that the medications have reduced her life expectancy and that she only has a few days to live. Veronika falls in love with a person suffering from schizophrenia within the confines of a mental hospital. The hospital's head psychiatrist is attempting to conduct an experiment involving Veronika somehow. What is causing this, and why is it happening? That is the plot of the story. Veronika Decides to Die is a critically acclaimed novel partially based on the author's experiences in mental facilities. The novel has been translated into 46 languages and has been adapted for several stage productions. The novel has also garnered a lot of positive feedback from critics.

Eleven Minutes

‘Eleven Minutes’ is the masterpiece of Brazilian bestselling author Paulo Coelho. This novel is based on a fictional account of a woman named Maria who lives in Rio but moves to Geneva. She is poor and has to do menial jobs to survive in Geneva. Fate led her to be a prostitute. She has accepted her life this way and keeps going, displaying great strength. During one of her walks down a street, she feels a sexual awakening inside her. The quest for physical pleasure leads her into interesting situations where she tries to find her own body and desires. While living a life of a prostitute, trying to understand herself sexually, she comes across a man. She crosses paths with a young painter. His charm instantly smits her, and he is captivated by Maria too. There is a chance that she might fall in love. Love has found her door; will she let it in? Or will it be another sexual adventure for her? This honest tale of a woman's journey to understand her physically and emotionally is bound to keep you hooked till the last page. The descriptions are vivid and yet leave a lot to the imagination. You cannot categorise this as erotica; rather it will stir your soul and force you to think and look within.

Like The Flowing River

Like the Flowing River, published in 2006, is a departure from the mystery narrator-led stories we've seen until now. The book comprises short stories, notes, poetry, and anecdotes. The anthology addresses important issues, such as what dying means. What is the history of life? What brings us here? As with many of Paulo's writings, he won't give you straightforward answers to complex topics. Instead, he properly nudges you to encourage you to think about them.

By The River Piedra, I Sat Down & Wept

The book, released in 2021 By the Piedra River I Sat Down and Wept, is the story of an adolescent love renewed 11 years after the couple's childhood lovers split up. Pilar and her childhood-turned-handsome spiritual guru give themselves up to a slew of buried sentiments they believed were lost to history in the French Pyrenees. The pair's freshly rekindled love forces them to confront unpleasant memories, prompting the reader to reconsider their previous relationships and their understanding of what love entails.

Brida

Brida is the tale of a young Irish woman on a quest to understand life's more profound mysteries. Brida has always been interested in magic and wants to learn more about being a witch. Her quest leads her to strange places, and she encounters many interesting characters who help her find the answers she is seeking. Brida is young, has a good job, a great boyfriend who loves her and is quite happy in other ways. But she still longs to go on a spiritual journey of self-discovery.

FAQs: Best Paulo Coelho’s Books to Read

Q1. Which one is the best book of Paulo Coelho?

Ans. The Alchemist is regarded as one of the best books of Paulo Coelho. This book was published in 1988 in the Portuguese language. It teaches you to turn down all negative voices in your life. It became an international bestseller and has been translated into several languages.

Q2. Is The Alchemist for young adults?

Ans. The Alchemist, a quirky novella by Paulo Coelho, is the ideal self-help book for teenagers in high school because it is written in the style of an accessible tale, and the narrative serves to mask the preachy tone of works aimed to help adolescents find themselves and their place in the world.

Q3. In what order should I read the books of Paulo Coelho?

Ans. Paulo Coelho's works do not have a sequence and can be read in the order in which they were published. Beginning with "The Pilgrimage" in 1987, followed by the world-renowned "Alchemist" in 1988, and continuing with works such as "Brida" (1990) and "Veronika Decides to Die" (1998).
